reasoning: Biology is constrained by experiment throughput, clinical/ethical/regulatory delays, data and intrinsic complexity; intelligence can't instantly overcome these, so 50–100 years of progress in 5–10 is less likely.
This is a definitional threshold; Claim A about bottlenecks doesn't change whether this is how 'powerful AI' is defined.

Discovery (vs deployment) can be sped up by better design and automation, but lab throughput and data remain constraints; still, routing around over 5–10 years makes a ≥10x discovery speedup more plausible.
Clinical development is bottlenecked by human/legal constraints, recruitment, follow-up and real-world time; intelligence and better models help but can't compress most programs to ~1 year.

Achieving sweeping disease elimination and lifespan doubling in a decade collides with biological complexity, clinical/regulatory and global deployment bottlenecks that intelligence cannot quickly erase.
Neuroscience advances depend on invasive measurement/intervention, data and ethics—hard physical/human bottlenecks—so compressing a century into 5–10 years is unlikely.
Distribution in low-income settings is constrained by logistics, governance and supply chains; intelligence helps plan but cannot quickly remove these frictions, tempering the 5–10 year target.
Sustained ~20% growth hinges on overcoming corruption/policy and absorption bottlenecks that intelligence can't instantly fix, making the ambition less likely.
Since political constraints are real bottlenecks, AI doesn't inherently favor one regime type; a deliberate entente strategy fits Claim A’s governance emphasis.
Given real institutional bottlenecks, AI leadership plus targeted tools can gradually route around some constraints to bolster democratic capacity.
Short-run complementarities from physical-world and institutional bottlenecks, followed by erosion as intelligence routes around them, matches Claim A’s dynamics.
Claim A is about how to reason under constraints, not timing; it neither supports nor undermines the 'gentle singularity' timeline.
Fast timelines—especially for competent physical robots—run into real-world speed and hardware/actuation bottlenecks; intelligence helps but not instantly.
Software-centric fields can see big gains and AI-for-AI loops, but broader science faces physical/data bottlenecks; acceleration is real yet not limitless.
Economic scaling and automation can route around many bottlenecks over time, pushing intelligence costs toward energy limits, consistent with Claim A.
Focusing on marginal returns aligns with observed scaling/cost trends; these do not clash with the bottleneck view and may reinforce investment.
Knowledge work has fewer physical bottlenecks; intelligence can be replicated cheaply, so junior-coworker agents are made more plausible.
Over longer horizons many bottlenecks can be routed around, changing capabilities while core human experiences persist; fits Claim A’s long-horizon view.
Heterogeneous bottlenecks imply uneven industry impact and sharper price declines where constraints are weaker (e.g., bits vs atoms).
Alignment and governance are human/legal bottlenecks that must be addressed in parallel with scaling—precisely the kind of constraint Claim A highlights.
Policy co-evolution and user empowerment address human/legal bottlenecks and mitigate authoritarian misuse, matching Claim A’s framing.
Sharing access to intelligence (compute budgets, low costs) targets distributional/institutional bottlenecks rather than assuming intelligence alone fixes them.
Even by 2035, 'unlimited genius' is bounded by data, coordination, and physical-world bottlenecks; intelligence helps but doesn’t erase these limits.
